data.message: Hello TSP members! Many thanks to those of you who have done our first follow-up survey sent out two weeks ago. For those of you who haven't, don't forget to check your email and complete it for a $20 gift card! You’ll earn an additional $20 at the end if you fill out all surveys!

Just a friendly reminder to check your email and fill out the first follow-up survey that we sent out last week. Remember, you'll receive $20 for completing it and will receive an additional $20 at the end if you complete all follow-up surveys!

That's wonderful news, 10259! Best of luck!!! Let us know if you need any tips/resources :)-Shirley from TSP

Hello TSP members! Today's post concludes our 90-day program. Please check your email today for our first follow-up survey. You will receive a $20 gift card upon completion.We hope that our Facebook group has been enjoyable, educational, and life-changing in some way, whether it be a shift in your perspective towards smoking, or a commitment towards a healthier, smoke-free life. All of us at TSP have enjoyed reading your comments and interacting with you online, and we truly thank you for your participation.Although we will no longer be posting daily, you are welcome to remain in this secret group and access all of the content we've shared over the past 90 days. Furthermore, we're still available to answer any questions/concerns about smoking, and we're open to any feedback/suggestions you may have for our program.Again, from all of us at TSP, thank you and good luck in your future endeavors!

10278 how is your smoking reduction going? Are you still on track?

Also don't forget to reward yourself to stay motivated:

That's ok - no worries! You are well prepared and have strong reasons for quitting and staying smoke free - so you shouldn't worry too much about relapsing. Also, it's up to you if a lapse will lead to a full blown relapse. Even if you lapse you should tell yourself that this happens to a lot of smokers trying to quit and that it doesn't mean you have to go back to the way things were. Throw away your cigs, lighter etc. and go back to quitting! Do you think this may help?

When im anxious or angry is when i smoke the most

data.message: #65: Here’s a story of James, a 22-year-old man who quit smoking after starting before he was even 15. Tell us if his Quit Letter inspired you to find new reasons to quit or to reach out to someone else close to you who is trying to do the same. #reflection

data.caption: quitsmoking.about.com
data.description: A diagnosis of cancer at the age of 20 was the final straw that helped James decide to quit smoking for good.

data.message: I like how it wasn't an article about "smoking did this to me..." its "this is what happened  not clearly from smoking but it helped me stop". Too often i see the commercials and ads where there's someone in a wheelchair because of smoking. While its a little encouraging, its more of the same thing over and over again. So i would say yes, this  helped

10278 - I have some more suggestions and resources that you may find useful: Quick stress relief at home  Entertaining. Prevent pre-party jitters by playing lively music. Light candles. The flicker and scent will stimulate your senses. Wear clothes that make you feel relaxed and confident instead of stiff and uncomfortable. Kitchen. Cool the kitchen commotion by breathing in the scent of every ingredient you use—even if you’re just opening cans. Delight in the delicate texture of an eggshell. Appreciate the weight of an onion. Children and relationships. Prevent losing your cool during a spousal spat by breathing and squeezing the tips of your thumb and forefinger together. When your toddler has a tantrum, rub lotion into your hands then breathe in the scent.   Sleep. Too stressed to snooze? Try using a white noise machine for background sound or a humidifier with a diffuser for a light scent in the air.    Creating a sanctuary. If clutter is upsetting, spend 10 minutes each day to tidy and organize. Paint the walls with a fresh coat of your favorite calming color. Display photos and images that make you feel happy. Throw open the curtains and let in natural light whenever possible.
http://www.helpguide.org/articles/stress/stress-relief-in-the-moment.htm

Hi Everyone, I am switching things up and doing The Doctor Is In a bit later this week. What are people dealing with this week? Has anyone in this group tried to quit smoking? If so, how did it go? If not, what is getting in your way?

Hang in there, 10259, it is not easy to quit. Do you have a plan of when you want to quit this time around?

I have not to be honest, I know someone who tried them and it gave her muscle cramps which I don't want, but I have been looking at them more recently cause I feel like that's a legitimate concern but at the same time I know I'm also making excuses haha, but does it matter what brand you use or are they all the same?

No, it does not matter. The strength does matter though, and you should use the strength that makes sense depending on how many cigarettes you smoke each day. If you smoke more than 10 cigs per day start with the 21 or 15 mg patch (highest dose). If fewer than 10, you can start wiht the middle does (either 14 or 10).

I like to leave you guys with tips in these session, so today, here is our 5-step TSP quit plan. See if something resonates with you: 1. GET READY.• Set a quit date and stick to it – not even a single puff! 2. GET SUPPORT AND ENCOURAGEMENT.• Tell your family, friends and coworkers you are quitting.• Talk to your doctor or other health care provider.• Get group, individual, or telephone counseling. Think about who can support you with quitting smoking3. LEARN NEW SKILLS AND BEHAVIORS.• When you first try to quit, change your routine.• Reduce stress.• Distract yourself from urges to smoke.• Plan something enjoyable to do every day.• Drink a lot of water and other fluids. Think about which of these will be most helpful to you?4. GET MEDICATION AND USE IT CORRECTLY.Talk with your health care provider about which medication will work best for you:• Medication: bupropion, verenicline (prescription).• Nicotine Replacement:-gum and patch are over-the-counter-inhaler and nasal spray are prescriptionIs there one of these that you think would be helpful for you?5. BE PREPARED FOR RELAPSE OR DIFFICULT SITUATIONS.• Avoid alcohol.• Be careful around other smokers.• Improve your mood in ways other than smoking.• Eat a healthy diet and stay active.

Hi Guys, welcome to TSP! In addition to daily posts, we also have weekly sessions with a live person who can talk to you about smoking and quitting. It's usually Johannes Thrul, but today you are getting me. I am an Assistant Professor of Psychiatry at UCSF in San Francisco and creator of TSP. Happy to answer any questions you have - I'm here for an hour.
Hello Dr. Ramo. I was curious which method of quitting smoking was the most effective?  I have tried a lot a ways, but I always break.
god question 10258. It partially depends on how much you smoke and what has worked and not worked in the past. What have you tried before?
I've tried cold turkey, the patch, and lozenges.

In general, preparing to quit and setting a clear quit date is a good strategy no matter what. Then having nicotine replacement therapy like patch or lozenge or gum on hand is a good idea to use as soon as you reach your quit date. We can also talk about other good strategy to help you get ready. Do you already have a new quit date in mind?
Not quite.  But shortly

Ok, well that is a good strategy to start. Then preparing for that date, we recommend that you: 1. tell anyone and everyone that you are quitting; 2. get your nicotine replacement therapy or other medication ready - you can talk to a doctor about what might work best for you or buy some at the store if it is over the counter. As you get closer to the date, you can: 3. get rid of everything that reminds you of smoking. Are those things that you did in the past or not so much?
Gotta run, but I will be here two more weeks and we can follow-up on any other issues you are thinking about or questions before our regular counselor Johannes Thrul is back. Great chatting today!

data.message: Welcome to the Tobacco Status Project! Thank you for joining us -- we're so excited to have you here. We will share our first post in just a FEW MINUTES! Here's how it works: 1) We will share one post everyday for 90 days. Remember to turn on Notifications (top right corner) and check this page daily!2) Your group has been randomly assigned to a Weekly Incentive. To earn money, you must comment on ALL posts we share each week. You will earn $7 if you've commented on all 7 posts, and $0 if you comment on 6 or less. We'll tally your comments every week, and you'll have a new chance to earn money at the start of the next week. You will receive a gift card for the money you've earned at the end of the 90-day program.3) Dr. Danielle Ramo will be joining us for 1 hour each week, for the first 3 weeks, during which she will answer any tobacco-related questions, share info and resources, and provide support to our group. Stay tuned for her first session TODAY at 4pm! After the first 3 weeks, Dr. Johannes Thrul will be taking over the sessions.
4pm in which time zone?
I've managed to cut down a lot just by drinking water when I'm craving a cigarette.
Read an article about how eating something salty when your craving a cigarette is suppose to help
I find that drinking water when I have the urge to smoke really helps. Plus all of this extra water is really good for you!
I like sunflower seeds.   I chew on those a lot when I have the urge.   It actually helped me quit one year..  But I made the mistake by having one cigarette and it was all down hill from there.
I like sunflower seeds too! And lollipops help as well.
So far I've cut down by 5 or 6 a day. I've found that chewing gum when I have the urge to smoke helps keep me from giving in.
Ended up back at square one today :/ smoked 5 cigarettes...
I managed to cut back by a few today.
Way to go!   I cut down also.  Usually I smoke anywhere from half a pack to a full pack a day.  I've only had 3 cigarettes today!
Cut down alot today!

Ive been smoking on and off for 4 years now. I have quit a couple times. First time was a short period and went right back to it as soon as i could (a week). Second time was longer because i was pregnant. ( didnt smoke once i found out). And the last time was for about a month. I always end up going back because its literally a habit in my everyday life. Wake up smoke, smoke a few hours later. Have lunch smoke. Smoke a few hours later. Its always worse when my fiance gets home because we ate both smokers so when he goes i want to ect.
Looking forward to the tips on how to quit.

I am really excited about this study group. I have been a smoker for 12 years now. Failing to quit time after time, I still have the desire to stop. Yet can never fully complete the quitting process. I'm interested to see if the information and the support from this group will help me to commit and stop.

I hear ya man. I've been smoking since I was 14. I'm 21 now and I've tried quitting at least half a dozens times. I can't even make it through the first 24 lol. My whole family smokes, so its not like I get a ton of support from them. Not that I blame them; it is what it is.
I understand, I've tried to quit multiple times but it never seems to last..
Yeah guys, it's rough. Maybe we can help out each other.
In the same boat.   Ive been smoking for 7 years and I'm 21.  I've tried to quit unsuccessfully multiple times.   We can all do this together!
I've been smoking for 5 years and am looking to quit while I'm still young.
Anyone have any tips or things that they have tried that have seem to work, or things that they have not had any success with?

data.message: What is the best way to stop craving?

Hi 10270 - great question. Here are some options that may be helpful: http://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-living/quit-smoking/in-depth/nicotine-craving/art-20045454 Do any of these sound like good options for you?
I have tried those but they don't seem to work for me very well. Especially with griving and drinking

10270 is there anything that has worked for you in the past? In my experience some of these things work for a lot of people: Keep your hands busy: Use a stress ball, play a game on your phone, play with a Rubik’s cube, start a fun arts and crafts project. Keep your mouth busy: Use gum, hard candy, mints, chew on toothpicks, prepare healthy snacks like veggie sticks, drink plenty of water.Any of these sound useful?
